bibl.title: Letter from John D. Schwieger to Albert E. Truby, June 21, 1933

div1.p: Schwieger, who served with Truby in Cuba, requests Truby's assistance in retaining his pension.

div1.head: Letter from John D. Schwieger to Albert E. Truby, June 21, 1933
div1.opener:
John D. Schwieger
4752 Kewanee Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
June 21- 1933
Dr. A. E. Truby
Brigadier Gen. Med. Dept
Washington D. C.:
Dear Sir and Comrade:
div1.p:
I was very much pleased and delighted
to hear from you, and am most grateful for
the certificate,. During my brief existance
while in the Army, and under your command
at Guanajay, Camp Columbia, and Cienfuegos, I
have had many officers whom I value very
highly in my memory. Head and shoulders
above them all stands Dr. A. E. Truby, who
always went about doing good. with never
a stern word, and always praises for my
work. Who would not have done his utmost
under those circumstances!

Have just received word from the
Pension Dept that beginning with July 1
this year I will be dropped from the roll.

I cannot make myself beleive that
that our work in exterminating yellow fever
and the far reaching results derived there from
John D. Schwieger
4752 Kewanee Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
shall be left unrewarded, This was rather
a sense jolt in the evening tide of ones life.

Should you ever come this way, give
my family and myself the extreme pleasure of
meeting you
div1.closer: Your old nurse John D. Schwieger Pension #1127039
